articles.headline: Contrarian Investor Sees Economic Crash in China
articles.snippet: James Chanos, who predicted Enron’s collapse, insists that the economic boom in China is headed for a fall.
articles.abstract: James Chanos, who predicted Enron’s collapse, insists that the economic boom in China is headed for a fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  James S. Chanos built one of the largest fortunes on Wall Street by foreseeing the collapse of Enron and other highflying companies whose stories were too good to be true.

articles.headline: A Safety Net That Tangles Investors
articles.snippet: Some who lost money to Bernard Madoff had a custodian agreement with a bank. So far, they are worse off because of that deal.
articles.abstract: Some who lost money to Bernard Madoff had a custodian agreement with a bank. So far, they are worse off because of that deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the wake of a series of Ponzi schemes  the most notable being the Bernard Madoff fraud  the Securities and Exchange Commission voted last month to tighten the rules and make it much harder for money managers to misappropriate client funds.

articles.headline: Obama Details New Policies in Response to Terror Threat
articles.snippet: President Obama ordered a series of steps to streamline how terrorism threats are pursued, after a review of the thwarted bombing revealed shortcomings.
articles.abstract: President Obama ordered a series of steps to streamline how terrorism threats are pursued, after a review of the thwarted bombing revealed shortcomings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday ordered intelligence agencies to take a series of steps to streamline how terrorism threats are pursued and analyzed, saying the government had to respond aggressively to the failures that allowed a Nigerian man to ignite an explosive mixture on a commercial jetliner on Christmas Day.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Fed Advice to A.I.G. Scrutinized
articles.snippet: Revelations that the government stopped A.I.G. from releasing bailout details called in to question whether the information had to be disclosed under federal securities law.
articles.abstract: Revelations that the government stopped A.I.G. from releasing bailout details called in to question whether the information had to be disclosed under federal securities law.
articles.lead_paragraph: New revelations that the government stopped the American International Group from revealing information about its bailout had securities lawyers and policy makers buzzing on Thursday about whether the information had to be disclosed under federal securities law, and if so, what to do about the lack of compliance.

articles.headline: NBC Wants Leno Back in Old Slot
articles.snippet: Faced with the failure of the biggest recent gamble in television, NBC is shuffling its late-night deck again.
articles.abstract: Faced with the failure of the biggest recent gamble in television, NBC is shuffling its late-night deck again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Faced with the failure of the biggest recent gamble in television, NBC is shuffling its late-night deck one more time.

articles.headline: Seeing Old Age as a Never-Ending Adventure
articles.snippet: The limitations of age are being tossed aside by active men and women as the global travel and leisure industry races to keep up.
articles.abstract: The limitations of age are being tossed aside by active men and women as the global travel and leisure industry races to keep up.
articles.lead_paragraph: OCALA, Fla.  Ilse Telesmanich, 90, sprained her ankle hiking in South Africa last August. She tried to keep going on the three-week trip, she said, hobbled as she was.

articles.headline: U.S. Job Losses in December Dim Hopes for Quick Upswing
articles.snippet: The government said the economy shed 85,000 jobs last month, surprising forecasters, while the unemployment rate held steady at 10 percent.
articles.abstract: The government said the economy shed 85,000 jobs last month, surprising forecasters, while the unemployment rate held steady at 10 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation lost 85,000 jobs from the economy in December, the Labor Department reported Friday, as hopes for a vigorous recovery ran headlong into the prospect that paychecks could remain painfully scarce into next year.
